intro.description: I’m here to help you overcome the obstacles standing in the way of your personal and professional growth — to reduce your distress, strengthen your sense of self, improve your relationships, and help you move toward self-actualization and a more fulfilling life.

approach.description1: My approach is integrative psychotherapy, combining elements of psychoanalysis, psychodynamic therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy and humanistic schools of therapy.
approach.description2: The choice of methods, frequency and duration of therapy are tailored to your individual needs, capacities and the nature of your struggles.

onlineTherapy.title: Advantages of online psychotherapy
onlineTherapy.description: Convenient and accessible - from the comfort of your own home, without losing energy and time on commuting. It also allows clients living abroad to work with a therapist from a similar cultural background (Balkan region) who can accurately understand and interpret emotional and behavioral patterns specific to that cultural context.

forWhom.title: Who is online psychitherapy for (common examples):
issues: Difficulties with anxiety, social anxiety and depressive symptoms
Feeling of chronic fatigue, stress and burnout
Difficulties regulating eating (emotional eating, uncontrolable overeating, obsessing over healthy eating, restrictive eating)

Relationship difficulties - fear of intimacy and abandonement, excessive jealousy or partner controlling behavior, overly addapting to your partners needs, difficulties to express your own needs, difficulties saying "no"
Withdrawal and avoidance of friendships and romantic relationships due to feelings of inadequacy
Lack of motivation, sense of purpose and dirrection
Feeling inauthentic, overly adjusted to others' expectations
Difficulties adjusting to and integrating into a new culture, living abroad
Chalenges adapting to new roles (parenthood, partnership, professional transitions)
Desire to reduce alcohol consumption, gambling, excessive gaming

biography.title: My professional background
biography.content: I graduated from the Faculty of Medicine in Novi Sad, Serbia in 2015 and became a licensed physician after passing the state exam. After a short period of work in general practice, I moved to the Netherlands in 2017. Following language certification and diploma recognition, I started working in 2020 at the University Medical Center Groningen, Department of Psychiatry. Three months later, I was accepted into the psychiatry residency program and began formal psychotherapy training.

specialFocus.description: I am particularly attuned to working with individuals of Balkan origin living abroad, who often struggle to adapt to a foreign culture and integrate, to form meaningful emotional connections, while preserving their personal and cultural identity and authenticity.

therapy.title: What does online psychotherapy look like?
therapy.initialMeeting: Before scheduling your first session, I offer a free 15-minute introductory meeting, which allows you to assess whether you want to begin working with me, and helps me evaluate whether psychotherapy is suitable for your needs.
therapy.firstSession: The first session focuses on mapping out key issues and understanding the broader context of your functioning.
therapy.furtherWork: Subsequent sessions are dedicated to reducing your difficulties and working toward your personal goals.
therapy.confidentiality: All information shared is strictly confidential, and you have the right to discontinue therapy at any time without explanation.
therapy.platform: Sessions are conducted via Zoom or Google Meet.

contact.title: How to contact me?
contact.instructions: You can fill out the contact form, or message me on WhatsApp, Viber or Telegram at +31 6 48569129 (Note: Dutch phone number — not an error.) First we will schedule a free 15-minute introductory conversation, followed by your first session.
contact.languages: I offer psychotherapy in Serbian, English and Dutch.

notSuitableFor.title: Who is online psychotherapy NOT suitable for:
conditions: Acute suicidal risk or self-harming behavior
Active psychosis, schizophrenia, or schizoaffective disorder
